title: What decade produced the best music? - Memory Lane - Quora

response.answer_text: What makes anyone think they can give a definitive answer to a question that can only be answered subjectively? Most of us, in the US anyway, begin to absorb the popular music that will influence us for the rest of our lives, by the time we are around twelve years old and that window stays open until we are maybe thirty or so. By the time the window closes we tend to think “oh, they’ve ruined popular music”, or something more negative yet. What has happened, here in the land of commerce, is that no one is designing popular music to sell to thirty something listeners, but only for early and late teens and you just noticed that you are no longer in that category. My musical tastes were formed first at home and in school, with classical music and a now somewhat pallid repertoire of watered down folk songs and Broadway show tunes. There was a folk music revival going on as I was coming of age in the early sixties and I found myself drawn to it as other kids were wallowing in rhythm n’ blues or or the sanitized white pop stolen from black artists as well as some of the material that had been synthesized into the products of producer/writer teams at the Brill Building in New York, such as Ellie Greenwich, Phil Spector and Carol King, Gerry Goffin. It wasn’t until I had digested the history of American folk music in a a very simple way that I came to understand and appreciate the diversity of our music from the early days to the time of my youth in the sixties that I realized that we all have this experience. My parents generation were complaining about how horrible rock and roll was and confused as to why my generation, initially at least, would not embrace Glenn Miller or Frank Sinatra, but those sounds were as foreign to most American teenagers (other than hearing their parents listen to it) as if it came from half way around the globe in another language. My window closed in the seventies for the most part (there are always exceptions) and I was unwilling to take Disco music seriously or after that new wave, punk or rap and hip hop. I realized that there was far too much recorded music already available to be explored that I did not need the new forms that were being put out in public. If I listen to popular music from the sixties and seventies, I hear a mixture of charm and mediocrity over all, no different than any other era, it’s just that it is in a form specific to the generation that it was substantially aimed at. Despite my detachment and indifference to much of popular culture and it’s strident commercialism, the farther away the era in question becomes the better it seems to look. Although a great deal of crap was produced in the fifties and sixties, my breath is taken away when I see old films showing Chuck Berry or the early Beatles presenting their particular art forms. Even some of the silly stuff still comes off as fun and refreshing today like Sam The Sham and Pharaohs singing Wooly Bully, for instance. Personally I think it is a grave mistake to think that any era was superior, it is all a continuum leading only in one forward direction, more and more a synthesis of the varieties of the past, which is what the pop music (and the country music and the jazz, etc) of the sixties was doing, just as is every other generation before or after.

My vote: the 60's ... all I can say is that in 1969 you were glad gas was 30¢ a gallon, because you had to scrape together your $5 bills to buy one great album after another, after the other ... one a week. The go back two more years … and it’s just pilinig on! Perhaps the two most influential years in rock history. As follows ... my selected list ... from the best year of the best (IMO) decade: The Sixties, 1969. (and then, as a bonus, 1967 as well) 1969 Album Releases January 1969 Yellow Submarine - some little band Bayou County - Creedence Clearwater Revival Led Zeppelin - Led Zeppelin February 1969 Goodbye Cream Kick of the Jams - MC5 March 1969 The Velvet Underground - The Velvet Underground April 1969 Nazz Nazz - Nazz (Todd Rundgren) Johnny Winter - Johnny Winter The Chicago Transit Authority - The Chicago Transit Authority On the Threshold of a Dream - Moody Blues Ramblin Gamblin Man - Bob Segar May 1969 Clouds - Joni Mitchell Stand! - Sly and the Family Stone Everybody Knows This is Nowhere - Neil Young Tommy - The Who Crosby, Stills and Nash - Crosby, Stills and Nash The Age of Aquarius - The 5th Dimension June 1969 A Salty Dog - Procol Harum Beck-Ola - Jeff Beck Group Brave New World - Steve Miller Band Deep Purple - Deep Purple Lee Michaels - Lee Michaels July 1969 Blind Faith - Blind Faith Mountain - Leslie West August 1969 Green River - Creedence Clearwater Revival The Stooges - The Stooges Songs for a Tailor - Jack Bruce On Time - Grand Funk Railroad My Cherie Amour - Stevie Wonder Santana - Santana September 1969 Then Play On - Fleetwood Mac (Peter Green) Abbey Road - some little band October 1969 In the Court of the Crimson King - King Crimson Led Zeppelin II Ticket to Ride - The Carpenters Wedding Album - John and Yoko November 1969 Volunteers - Jefferson Airplane David Bowie - David Bowie Joe Cocker! - Joe Cocker Mott the Hoople - Mott the Hoople The Allman Brothers - The Allman Brothers Band December 1969 Let it Bleed - some other little band Grand Funk - Grand Funk Railroad Blue Cheer - Blue Cheer  If that's enough all on its own ... here's highlights of 1967: January 1967 The Doors Between The Buttons - The Stones February 1967 Strawberry Fields/Penny Lane - some little band March 1967 The Velvet Underground and Nico The Who and Cream both appear in the US for the first time, in NYC Mellow Yellow - Donovan Happy Together - The Turtles May 1967 Are You Experienced - Hendrix May 2, Beach Boys -- Smile is cancelled ... a dark day June 1967 Sgt. Peppers - some little abnd Monterey Pop introduces Jimi Hendrix to the US Jagger and Richards sentenced to jail ... The Stones' Flowers album released July 1967 Bee Gees 1st Hendrix thrown off the Monkees US tour (he was the opening act) ... for being too lewd August 1967 Big Brother and the Holding Company Pink Floyd's first album, The Piper at the Gates of Dawn Vanilla Fudge September 1967 Procol Harum Altho Guthrie - Alice's Restaurant October 1967 Rolling Stone Magazines first issue (John Lennon on the cover) Buffalo Springfield - Buffalo Springfield Again November 1967 Days of Future Past - Moody Blues Magical Mystery Tour - some little band Jefferson Airplane - After Bathing at Baxter's December 1967 Hendrix - Axis Bold as Love The Stones - Their Satanic Majesties Request  (Here's The Monkees' Peter Tork on Hendrix ...)

The 70’s hands down. Hard rock, punk rock, soft rock, southern fried rock, folk, disco, country, soul, R&B even rap music (in its infancy ). Great music was so diversified in the 70’s. Most of my all time favor music came out of that decade (my first 10 yrs on earth). You could be rockin out so hard to Ted Nugents “Stranglehold” one minute and the next be crying in your beer over Jim Croces hauntingly beautiful “Time in a bottle.” Or spittin dope rhymes with Blondies “Rapture” or screaming along until you lose your voice with Janis Joplin’s “Another little piece of my heart.” Or maybe disco was your scene and you just wanted to “Keep dancing the night away” with The Bee Gees. Or maybe you lived on the wrong side of the tracks and liked to slam dance, spit on people and jump around with The Romones and The Sex Pistols. The 70s were a decade full of dark and weary times but its music inspired some of the absolute best music ever. The Eagles, Queen, ELO, Elton John, Carol Carpenter, Grand Master Flash, Lynard Skynard, Fleetwood Mac James Taylor, The Comadores, Captain & Tennile, Tom Petty, Chicago, Blue Oyster Cult…. The list goes on and on. Classics. Music that still stands the test of time.
